turn.text: The state is community in a broader sense?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: It is -- the best --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So is the United States?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: The best answer I can give you is that, that is not the kind of complaint that HUD has received --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you just made the point that Trafficante must, its logic must take us way beyond a single apartment complex, now how far beyond?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: Probably to the point where the complainants are realistically being affected.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Maybe as a resident of Illinois, I do not like having any non-disaggregated community in the entire state in which I live.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: Well, it isn't their feelings being hurt, it is --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I am hurt by it.
I say I am hurt?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: [Attempt to Laughter] Well, the question is whether the way they have to live is affected by unlawful practices of someone else that the Congress has proscribed and that they are complaining of, not whether their feelings are hurt because the law is not being observed by everyone in the country or in their state.
It is always difficult to formulate these things with exactitude.
I can tell you that HUD does not undertake investigations at the behest of people who do not in someway allege that they are affected.
For example --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Economically affected or how?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: No, they do not require a pleading the way a court might, but for example, if they got a complaint from a former employee of a real estate company that the company was engaging in steering practices and that employee does not anyway say that he is still in that community and is affected by those practices.
HUD does not initiate an investigation, instead it will refer that complaint to the Department of Justice for us to see whether there is a violation to be investigated.
The same thing is true of an anonymous complaint.
It has to be a complaint from someone who shows that something is affecting him, his life and his community, he is someway affected --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But not necessarily economically, he does not have to show that --

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- twice the value of cost of the market price of his house is going down?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: No, he just has to show a direct interest of his own.
And we do what we can to enforce the statute.
The Court in Trafficante noted that the housing Section of the civil rights division had less than two dozen lawyers at that time.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And therefore relied on private attorneys general?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And I just wondered how many private attorneys general there are?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: Well, we hope enough to enforce the statute.
We now have only 21 attorneys in that same Section.
And it has the additional responsibility of enforcing the equal credit law as well as the fair housing law.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is the red line to which --

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: That is correct Mr. Justice Stewart.
And so it still has to be private enforcement that is the primary tool to bring about the congressional purpose here.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Wallace, on this question of the scope of Trafficante, you know, apparently Bellwood had some 20 or 25,000 people and that if we have to compare to 8,200 in Trafficante, but then I just recall that the complaints actually concern a limited area within Bellwood, does not it?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: Well, they specified --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Does that go across in the Maywood, I am not sure of it?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: They specified a limited area to which black customers were being steered.
That was part of the specificity of the complaint, but I do not think the complaint specified that as the only area affected by the steering.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I see, so the relevant number of people for purposes of comparison is the population of Bellwood?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_wallace
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace
turn.text: I would say so Your Honor.
Thank you, my time is expired.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well Mr. Wallace.
Do you have anything further Mr. Howe?

turn.speaker: jonathan_t_howe
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan T. Howe
turn.text: Yes, may it please the Court.
Much has been said about the Trafficante decision in this argument.
I think the Court's attention should be directed to page 212 of the opinion wherein the Court stated, we reverse and remand the case to the District Court leaving untouched all other questions.
And I think this follows right after the statement by Mr. Justice Douglas stating, we can give vitality to Section 810 (a) only by a generous construction.
So I think that all other questions in Trafficante were reserved and untouched by this Court.
One other factual --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The Court left open a 1982 question?

turn.speaker: jonathan_t_howe
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan T. Howe
turn.text: That is correct also Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it did not mention 812?

turn.speaker: jonathan_t_howe
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan T. Howe
turn.text: It did not mention it in the footnote but it dealt with the 1982 but it did in this language at the end, and then taking your concurring opinion to Mr. Justice White wherein you stated that you would limit it to the facts of the case as presented.
One other fact which is extremely important in the Trafficante decision is that the action was brought against a single landlord who alone controlled access to that apartment complex.
No one has alleged nor is there any reason to believe the two realtors doing business outside of the Village of Bellwood itself have a dramatic impact upon housing patterns within Bellwood.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that would almost go to the merits?

turn.speaker: jonathan_t_howe
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan T. Howe
turn.text: It could Your Honor, but I think that the fact that we like to point out is that there is a distinction between the class of defendants in Trafficante as to the class of defendant in this particular case.

The concept of the public policy argument as advanced by the United States, no showing has been made that by opening an opportunity under Section 3612 to indirect victims that the policy of the Fair Housing Act would be advanced.

And we would submit that it would be to the contrary because it would provide a mechanism by which the entire metrics of an administrative remedy through Section 3610 could be avoided and circumvented.

We think that the language of Section 3610 of person aggrieved is unique and the failure of Congress to include that language specifically in Section 3612 indicated a different view by Congress and we need to only look at the natural meaning of the words contained in the statute to go forward with that.
The fact that the attorney general's office lacked staff is no reason for this Court to make any consideration as to how it is going to interpret a statute.
It must do that solely and exclusively on the basis of what is contained in the statute.

We submit that we know of no other statute in the United States that would allow the systematic circumvention of remedies, if this court is to adopt the position that has been advanced by the plaintiffs.

It is necessary to confine an actionable claim within the limits of the language used by Congress and consistent with the logic that is embodied in that statutory scheme rather than allowing it to extend beyond the intentions of Congress.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
